additionalProperty.name: Rate Changes
additionalProperty.value: Lower rates → cheaper credit, risk-on; higher rates → tighter conditions, risk-off.

additionalProperty.name: QE / QT
additionalProperty.value: QE adds liquidity and suppresses yields; QT withdraws liquidity and can lift yields.

additionalProperty.name: Forward Guidance
additionalProperty.value: Communication that steers expectations for the future policy path.

additionalProperty.name: Typical Cross-Asset Reactions
additionalProperty.value: Easier policy: stocks↑, yields↓ (bonds↑), domestic FX↓, growth-linked commodities↑. Tighter policy: stocks↓, yields↑ (bonds↓), domestic FX↑, commodities mixed.

additionalProperty.name: Key Releases to Watch
additionalProperty.value: Rate decisions, CPI/PCE, employment/NFP, GDP, minutes and press conferences.

overview.title: Overview
bullets: Central-bank policy — especially policy-rate changes — is a primary tool to control inflation, stabilize currencies and influence growth.
Policy rates cascade into borrowing costs, consumer demand, investment decisions and, ultimately, asset prices across markets.
In fundamental analysis, tracking decisions and guidance helps traders anticipate shifts in macro conditions and market trends.

keyConcepts.title: Key Concepts in Central Bank Policies and Interest Rates

items.monetaryPolicy: Monetary Policy: Management of the economy via money supply and interest rates. Encompasses expansionary (rate cuts) and contractionary (rate hikes) stances.
items.interestRates: Interest Rates: Benchmark rates set or targeted by central banks. Lower rates cheapen credit and stimulate spending; higher rates restrain demand.
items.qe: Quantitative Easing (QE): Large-scale asset purchases to inject liquidity and compress yields, often during downturns.
items.guidance: Forward Guidance: Communications that signal likely future policy, anchoring market expectations for the path of rates.

stocks.title: 1. Stock Markets
bullets: Lower rates typically support equities by reducing financing costs and encouraging expansion and risk appetite.
Higher rates can weigh on valuations and profits via pricier credit and softer consumer demand.

fx.title: 2. Foreign Exchange (Forex) Markets
bullets: Higher domestic rates tend to attract capital inflows and strengthen the currency.
Lower rates often weaken the currency as flows seek better yields abroad.

bonds.title: 3. Bond Markets
bullets: Bond prices move inversely to yields; rate hikes pressure existing bond prices, while cuts usually lift them.
Policy direction shapes government and corporate yields, directly impacting fixed-income returns.

commodities.title: 4. Commodity Markets
bullets: Lower rates can stimulate growth and boost demand for oil, metals and other cyclicals.
Higher rates often coincide with slower activity, softening demand and prices.

items.label: Interest-Rate Decisions
items.text: Regular announcements on changes to policy or benchmark rates.

items.label: Inflation Reports
items.text: CPI/PCE targets guide tightening or easing when inflation deviates from goals.

items.label: Employment Data
items.text: Strong labor markets can prompt hikes; weak data may lead to cuts or QE.

items.label: GDP Growth
items.text: Faster growth can trigger higher rates to prevent overheating; slowdowns can invite easing.

benefits.title: Benefits of Understanding Central Bank Policies
bullets: Helps anticipate market moves and timing by aligning with policy cycles.
Applies across assets — relevant for stocks, FX, bonds and commodities.
Informs long-term positioning through clearer read-through on the macro cycle.

limitations.title: Limitations of Relying on Central Bank Policies
bullets: Unpredictability: Policy can change abruptly in crises or when data shifts.
Lagged effects: Rate moves take time to filter through to the real economy.
Global spillovers: Other countries’ policies and cross-border flows can offset or amplify domestic actions.
